The capital of Illinois is Springfield in the central part of
the state. Although today, the state's largest population center is in and
around Chicago in the northeastern part of the state, the state's European
population grew first in the west, with French who settled along the
Mississippi River, and gave the area the name Illinois Country.

New York had been inhabited by tribes of Algonquian and
Iroquoian-speaking Native Americans for several hundred years
by the time the earliest Europeans came to New York. French colonists and Jesuit
missionaries arrived southward from Montreal for trade and proselytizing. In 1609
, the region was visited by Henry Hudson sailing for the Dutch East India Company.

The term 'six flags over Texas' refers to several nations
 that have ruled over the territory. Spain was the first European country
 to claim the area of Texas. France held a short-lived colony. Mexico controlled the
territory until 1836 when Texas won its independence, becoming an independent
Republic. In 1845, Texas joined the union as the 28th state. The state's annexation set
off a chain of events that led to the Mexican–American War in 1846.

As a result, {authority_type} resigned, probably trying to evade the investigation. {new_authority} was appointed as his interim

The situation in the area of railways has suddenly become escalated in recent days: bandits rob trains by shooting and killing the passengers now and then. The local police sheriff has still not succeeded in catching them. Be careful!
The rapid development of industrialization leads to the construction of new railways. As a result, new trade ways were built which are easy prey for bandits. Be careful by choosing a direction!

Transport companies are trying to be on top of things. They constantly produce new wagons so that the railway's carrying capacity will make it possible to increase the amount of transported cargo and passengers hence the owners are going to make more money.
By pursuing wealth the companies owners do not pay attention to the quality of their railways...as a result, the rails often break down making the passengers to suffer and have different problems

The American Quarter Horse is the most popular breed in the United States today. This horse is well known both as a race horse and for its performance in rodeos, horse shows and as a working ranch horse.

The Thoroughbred breed comes from three famous foundation sires that were imported into the UK early in the 18th century. The English Thoroughbred, which was bred for the purpose of wither riding or flat and jump racing, originated in Britain in the mid-18th century. It is said that no other horse breed can beat the Thoroughbred in speed and distance at the same time.

The Andalusian, also known as the Pure Spanish Horse or PRE, is a horse breed from the Iberian Peninsula. The breed was used as a tool of diplomacy by the Spanish government, and kings across Europe rode and owned Spanish horses. From the very beginning of their history, Andalusians have been used for both riding and driving. They were, and still are, known for their use in mounted bull fighting.

The Arabian or Arab horse is a breed of horse that originated on the Arabian Peninsula. Throughout history, Arabian horses have spread around the world by both war and trade, used to improve other breeds by adding speed, refinement, endurance, and strong bone. Today, Arabian bloodlines are found in almost every modern breed of riding horse.

The Akhal-Teke is a horse breed from Turkmenistan, where they are a national emblem. She has a reputation for speed and endurance, intelligence, and a distinctive metallic sheen. In 1935 when a group of Turkmen riders rode the 2500 miles from Ashgabat to Moscow in 84 days, including a three-day crossing of 235 miles of desert without water. Horse is also known for its form and grace as a show jumper.

It is one of the oldest, most numerous, and most successful of the warmbloods. Originally a carriage horse, infusions of Thoroughbred blood lightened it to make it more agile and useful for competition. The Hanoverian is known for a good temperament, athleticism, beauty, and grace.

The Marwari is a rare breed of horse from the Marwar region of India. The Marwari is primarily maintained for show, horse safaris, sport, ceremonial and religious purposes, and during earlier days in war. Marwaris are also used to play polo, sometimes playing against Thoroughbreds.

The Orlov Trotter is a horse breed with a hereditary fast trot, noted for its outstanding speed and stamina. It is the most famous Russian horse. During the 19th century, Orlov trotters were used mainly for riding and harness racing by Russian nobility. They were valued for their beauty and elegance combined with the ability to work hard.

The Standardbred breed registry was formed in United States in 1879 by the National Association of Trotting Horse Breeders. The name arose due to the standard required of breeding stock, to be able to trot or pace a mile within a certain time limit. Standardbreds tend to be more muscled and longer bodied than the Thoroughbred. This horses are known for their skill in harness racing, being the fastest trotting horses in the world.

The 12 Metre class is a rating class for racing sailboats that are designed to the International rule. The designation 12 Metre does not refer to any single measurement on the boat, and is not referencing the vessels overall length, rather, measures the sum of the components directed by the formula which governs design and construction parameters. This 12 Metre boat range 70 feet in length overall; it has a sloop-rigged, with masts roughly 80 feet tall.

Copper cladded oak on oak hull for safe operations in the tropics. Berths for 8 guests plus 2 crew members in 4 cabins. LOA 45.00 meter (147'), Hull 24 meter, Beam 8.85 meter, Draft 5.10 meter, Displacement 127 tons

Steel hull, teak deck. Sleeps 12 passengers in four cabins all with bathroom. Separate crew quarter with three cabins and pantry. LOA 55.00 meter (180'), Hull 35 meter, Beam 12.85 meter, Draft 7.10 meter, Displacement 180 tons

The yacht has a steel hull and aluminum superstructure in splendid condition. Designed for 20 passengers in six cabins. There is also a separate room for the crew with four cabins. LOA 75.00 meter (246'), Hull 45 meter, Beam 20.34 meter, Draft 10.8 meter, Displacement 250 tons

The hull is made of 11 mm u-boat steel. Designed for 45 passengers in 8 cabins. There is also a separate room for the crew with 6 cabins. LOA 105.00 meter (344'), Hull 65 meter, Beam 27.75 meter, Draft 12.10 meter, Displacement 300 tons

The hull is made of expensive wood. The timber planking and large deck skylights give the interior a beautiful feel. Designed for 75 passengers in 14 cabins. There is also a separate room for the crew with 9 cabins. LOA 115.00 meter (377'), Hull 68 meter, Beam 30.45 meter, Draft 14.10 meter, Displacement 330 tons
Designed for 100 passengers in 16 cabins. There is also a separate room for the crew with 12 cabins. LOA 125.00 meter (410'), Hull 72 meter, Beam 34.15 meter, Draft 19.10 meter, Displacement 390 tons

The hull is made of mahogany & larch on oak frames. Teak deck, All accomodation in mahogany. Lead keel with bronce bolts, new sails. Designed for 120 passengers in 18 cabins. There is also a separate room for the crew with 13 cabins. LOA 135.00 meter (442'), Hull 78 meter, Beam 36.35 meter, Draft 21.10 meter, Displacement 430 tons

This is an extremely beautiful yacht, oak on oak, accomodation and deck in teak . Designed for 150 passengers in 21 cabins. There is also a separate room for the crew with 16 cabins, incl. crew for special events, wedding parties, harbor cruises, etc. LOA 135.00 meter (442'), Hull 78 meter, Beam 36.35 meter, Draft 21.10 meter, Displacement 430 tons

This is a two-storey simple house with a total covered area of 914 sq.m.ft. The first floor of the house consists of a living room, kitchen, corridor, equipped bathroom, veranda, stairs; the second floor of the house consists of two bedrooms, two terraces. There is also a small garden.

This is one of the first townhouses that was built in England in the early 19th century. During the construction, exclusive elements of decor were being used that creates an incredible impressive interior!
It's a pretty spacious cottage, an area of 380 sq.m. There are three separate rooms, three bedrooms, two living rooms and a large swimming pool. That's a great accommodation for a successful person!
That's a charming classic Roman-style villa by the sea! Furthermore the villa surrounded by a luxurious garden of orange and palm trees. It has one of the best locations in the West Villas!

That's really a historic building can take you back in time. And living in one can feel like a trip to a different era. It was built in the early 18th century; the four-bedroom estate features period wallpaper, heavy doors, and a half-acre yard that's perfect for hosting large gatherings. By far, this house is an indicator of an owner status!

The Italian-style house, an area of 700 sq.m.ft., was built in the middle of the 18th century on a parcel of land of over 2 hectares. The residence has 12 bedrooms, a swimming pool, a wine cellar in the cave and a few courtyards and delightful gardens!

The Mansion, an area of 2000 sq.m.ft., is located on a parcel of land of over 8 hectares. You can hunt, go fishing there. There is a stable! This place is famous for hosting such guests as Edward VII, George V!

This gigantic medieval castle, located in Cong, near Ireland’s border, is the oldest in Ireland. Its origins can be traced back to 1500. Over the years, it has grown into a monumental master-piece. On a parcel of land of over 600 acres you can see a tremendous number of olive trees as well as a deer park!

The palace was built in the 17th century surrounded by beautiful gardens with a statue of the former French monarch Louis XIV! A parcel of land of over 800 acres. There is a power station as well as a dining room over 200 meters long, 60 bathrooms, 4 pools, a golf course.

This coin called "Lucky". The legend of the "Lucky" Angel started in the unluckiest of all places, waiting in line for a meeting with the guillotine. During the French Revolution, the coin’s designer, Augustin Dupre, was spared from losing his head at the last minute. The "Lucky" legends continued, with sea captains and fighter pilots in both world wars believing the coin brought them luck.

The 1930 penny is without doubt the one rare coin that most Australians know about. The coin was first introduced in 1911, and stopped being minted in 1964, with the introduction of decimalisation. The obverse of the coin featured the reigning Australian monarch. The coin is one of just six proofs struck at the Melbourne Mint, and one of three which remain in private hands.

The Flowing Hair dollar was the first dollar coin issued by the United States federal government. Its size and weight were based on the Spanish dollar, which was popular in trade throughout the Americas. Throughout its history, the 1794 dollar has widely been considered one of the rarest and most valuable of all United States coins.
Golden Dinar Hashimi is the first coin in the list whose cost is at least a million dollars. This coin used in the 7th century on the island of Arabia, so it's one of the oldest gold coins.

The Brasher Doubloon was the first American gold coin. It’s maker is Ephraim Brasher. Brasher and Washington were well acquainted, and to this day silverware hallmarked "EB" can be found in the collection of the White House, including the original receipts.

The 1804 dollar or Bowed Liberty Dollar was a dollar coin struck by the Mint of the United States, of which fifteen specimens are currently known to exist. All coins were minted at Philadelphia. The obverse of coin has the image of the Statue of Liberty.
This coin is minted in honor of the coronation of Emperor Pedro I of Brazil. A total of 64 pieces were issued; how many were saved nowadays is unknown.

The 1913 Liberty Head nickel is an American five-cent piece which was produced in extremely limited quantities unauthorized by the United States Mint, making it one of the best-known and most coveted rarities in American numismatics. More than 570 millions of copies were minted for all the time.

The Edward III double florin, known as a double leopard and with a face value of six shillings, was circulated from December 1343 until July 1344. It is only the third known surviving coin, with two others found in the River Tyne in 1857.

The Rolls-Royce 10 hp was the first car to be produced as a result of an agreement of 23 December 1904 between Charles Rolls and Henry Royce. The 10 hp was produced by company of Royce, Royce Ltd., at its factory in Cooke Street, Hulme, Manchester. The engine is a water-cooled twin-cylinder of 1800 cc. It was intended to make a run of 20 of the cars but only 16 were made as it was thought that a twin-cylinder engine was not appropriate for the marque. The last 10 hp was made in 1906.

This model was introduced in February 1928. The straight eight model J motor was based on the successful racing engines company of the 1920s and though designed by Duesenberg they were manufactured by Lycoming, another company owned by Cord. In normally aspirated form, it produced 265 horsepower from dual overhead camshafts and four valves per cylinder. It was capable of a top speed of 119 mph. Other cars featured a bigger engine but none of them surpassed its power.

This Bugatti Type 41 Royale was the brainchild of Ettore Bugatti Ettore Bugatti. The Type 41 Royale engine had massive displacement: 12.7 liters, or over 700 cubic inches, roughly twice the size of most of the largest production V-8s that would be built by Detroit four decades later. This is still the largest engine of any car to be sold privately. A mere 6 cars were produced and 2 were never sold, staying instead with the Bugatti estate.

It was based on the 1935 Aerolithe concept car designed by Jean Bugatti. Like the Type 59 Grand Prix car, the Aerolithe used Elektron or Duralumin for its body panels. However, the production Atlantics, just four built, used plain aluminum. Three of the original four cars are known to survive.

In 1905, Buick would only produce the Model C, which really was a virtual carbon copy of the Model B. By year end, a total of 750 Model C Buicks would be built. This example is one of only 14 known to exist today. It is powered by a two-cylinder opposed engine with a bore and stroke of 4.5 x 5, displacing 159 cubic-inches and developing 22 horsepower.

The Ford Model A was the second successful vehicle model for the Ford Motor Company, after its predecessor, the Model T. First produced on October 20, 1927, but not introduced until December 2, it replaced the venerable Model T, which had been produced for 18 years. The engine was a water-cooled L-head inline four with a displacement of 201 cu in. This engine provided 40 hp. Top speed was around 65 mph.

Hot rods are typically old, classic American cars with large engines modified for linear speed. The first hot rods were old cars - most often Fords, typically Model Ts, 19 28–31 Model As, or 1932-34 Model Bs -, modified to reduce weight. Some automotive historians say that the term originated with stolen vehicles being refitted with another engine and repainted.

The Ford Model T is an automobile produced by Ford Motor Company from October 1, 1908, to May 26, 1927. It is generally regarded as the first affordable automobile, the car that opened travel to the common middle-class American. The first production Model T was produced on August 12, 1908 and left the factory on September 27, 1908, at the Ford Piquette Avenue Plant in Detroit, Michigan.

Mercedes Benz 540k Special Roadster is a car built by the German firm Mercedes-Benz from 1935 to 1940. Gustav Rohr engineered it, Hermann Ahrens designed it and Karosserie Sindelfingen built it. Powered by straight-eight 5.4 liter supercharged engine coupled with four-speed semi-automatic transmission, she featured independent suspension with coil spring and was capable of reaching 115 mph on German Autobahns.

The Starry Night is an oil on canvas by the Dutch post-impressionist painter Vincent van Gogh. Painted in June 1889, it depicts the view from the east-facing window of his asylum room at Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, just before sunrise, with the addition of an idealized village.

The Young Sick Bacchus, also known as the Sick Bacchus or the Self-Portrait as Bacchus, is an early self-portrait by the Baroque artist Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio, dated between 1593 and 1594. It now hangs in the Galleria Borghese in Rome. According to Caravaggio's first biographer, Giovanni Baglione, it was a cabinet piece painted by the artist using a mirror. The Sick Bacchus was among the many works making up the collection of Giuseppe Cesari.

The Last Day of Pompeii is a large history painting by Karl Bryullov produced in 1830–1833 on the subject of the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in AD 79. It is notable for its positioning between Neoclassicism, the predominant style in Russia at the time, and Romanticism as increasingly practised in France.

The painting represents a morning in the suburbs of Paris where the artist lives for some time wanting to get rid of the urban stuff and enjoy his work. Argenteuil is situated on the Seine, nine kilometers to the north-west of Paris, and Monet rented a house there in 1871 soon after his return to France after the Franco-Prussian War. Claude Monet painted the Argenteuil Bridge seven times, and the railway bridge which spans the Seine upstream from the village, four times.

The painting shows Jesus, in Renaissance dress, giving a benediction with his right hand raised and two fingers extended, while holding a transparent rock crystal orb in his left hand, signaling his role as savior of the world and master of the cosmos, and representing the 'crystalline sphere' of the heavens, as it was perceived during the Renaissance. It is one of fewer than 20 known works by Leonardo.

The Sistine Madonna, also called the Madonna di San Sisto, is an oil painting by the Italian artist Raphael Sanzio. The painting was commissioned in 1512 by Pope Julius II for the church of San Sisto, Piacenza. The canvas was one of the last Madonnas painted by Raphael. Giorgio Vasari called it a truly rare and extraordinary work. The painting was moved to Dresden from 1754 and is well-known for its influence in the German and Russian art scene.

It is a life-sized depiction of the character Danae from Greek mythology, the mother of Perseus. She is presumably depicted as welcoming Zeus, who impregnated her in the form of a shower of gold. This is one of Rembrandt's most magnificent paintings.
The painting by the Italian artist Sandro Botticelli probably made in the mid 1480s. It depicts the goddess Venus arriving at the shore after her birth, when she had emerged from the sea fully-grown.

Girl with a Pearl Earring is an oil painting by Dutch Golden Age painter Johannes Vermeer, dated c. 1665. The painting is a tronie, the Dutch 17th-century description of a 'head' that was not meant to be a portrait. It depicts a European girl wearing an exotic dress, an oriental turban, and an improbably large pearl earring.

An amphora is a type of container of a characteristic shape and size, descending from at least as early as the Neolithic Period. Amphorae were used in vast numbers for the transport and storage of various products, both liquid and dry, but mostly for wine.

The Aphrodite of Milos, better but mistakenly known as the Venus de Milo, is an ancient Greek statue and one of the most famous works of ancient Greek sculpture. Created sometime between 130 and 100 BC, the statue is believed to depict Aphrodite, the Greek goddess of love and beauty; however, some scholars claim it is the sea-goddess Amphitrite, venerated on Milos. The statue is named after the Greek island of Milos, where it was discovered.

This vase first appeared in the temples of the Tang dynasty (608–917 AD) as a holy water vase, also known as Yuhuchun. The shape was then popularized during the Song dynasty, and was mainly used as a wine vessel. Later, the refined shape became a classical vase style, and continues to be copied as a model. It is characterized by a slightly flared rim, a straight neck that broadens at the ends, a bottom-heavy body, and a short foot ring.

The dragon is a symbol of power, strength, and good luck for people who are worthy of it in East Asian culture. During the days of Imperial China, the Emperor of China usually used the dragon as a symbol of his imperial power and strength.

Clocks of this style are commonly 6,5 feet tall. The case often features elaborately carved ornamentation on the hood (or bonnet), which surrounds and frames the dial, or clock face. The English clockmaker William Clement is credited with the development of this form in 1670.

This original copy of the United States Constitution, written in 1787 during the Philadelphia Convention. The old Congress set the rules the new government followed in terms of writing and ratifying the new constitution. After ratification in eleven states, in 1789 its elected officers of government assembled in New York City, replacing the Articles of Confederation government.

This is one of the candelabra of the Spanish King Charles IV from the house of Luxembourg. It's a symbol of spiritual light and salvation. The number of its candles has always had a cosmic or mystical meaning.

The accepted history of the tea service begins in China during the Han Dynasty (206–220 BC). At this time, tea ware was made of porcelain and consisted of two styles: a northern white porcelain and a southern light blue porcelain. The tea service belongs to the Song Dynasty that used to produce exquisite ceramic teapots and tea bowls.

This is the first timepieces to be worn, made in 16th-century Europe, were transitional in size between clocks and watches. These 'clock-watches' were fastened to clothing or worn on a chain around the neck. The movement was made of iron or steel and held together with tapered pins and wedges.
The cognac recipe dates back to 1776. It was produced by the direct descendants of King Henry IV and consists of 3 grape varieties, and the delightful taste is known only to selected tasters!

Spanish cultivation of tobacco began in earnest in 1531 on the island of Santo Domingo. In 1542, tobacco started to be grown commercially in North America, when the Spaniards established the first cigar factory on the island of Cuba. This is a limited series causing a stir among fans of the real taste of tobacco!

Since 1810, six generations of the Kraug family have cultivated a uniquely exceptional Champagne through “painstaking care and unrivaled craftsmanship. Each bottle is a unique work of art from the sea, and the wine taste - crisp flavours of ripe orchard fruits.”

This brand is made with 18-year-old tobaccos and it boasts rich chocolate undertones. the infusion of the Louis XIII Cognac complements the flavor of the aged tobacco leaves. You will surely remember the amazing aroma and taste of this exquisite cigar for a long time.
This specific cognac features a blend of five distinct and rare eaux-de-vie from five different regions. The makers of this historic bottle of cognac have been in operation since the early 1700s.

What makes this cigar so exceptional is the unique blend of Mexican, Dominican and Nicaraguan tobacco, which is rolled up into habano lst. The cigars’ flavors are lovely and carry hints of spice and cocoa.
“It's an amazing rum with milk chocolate, orange peel, lots of vanilla, brown sugar and marzipan, as well as cinnamon, allspice and some dried oak rounding out the finish

These cigars were at least 100 years old and found in 1798 in Guatemala. The archaeologists discovered a pot made of clay and it was labeled sicars. It’s thought that this word is where the cigar comes from. They’re really well preserved and they can still be smoked. However, chances are no one wants to take a chance smoking this amazing part of history.

This standard bottle of wine, this vintage is believed to be from Thomas Jefferson’s cellar. The third president and one of the founding fathers was an ambassador to France and he’s said to spend much time visiting the Bordeaux and Burgundy vineyards for his wine collection.

A trophy is a tangible, durable reminder of a specific achievement, and serves as recognition or evidence of merit. Back in the day, trophies commemorated the military victories of a state, army or individual combatant. In the modern day trophy taking is reflected in hunting trophies.

The fur of a polar bear is really luxurious. It has always been considered the best trophy experienced hunters! This animal is considered a rare species therefore the fur of a polar bear is a recognized luxury all over the world raising the status of its owner!

Ask any taxidermist and they'll tell you that fish are the toughest animals to work with. The reason is that the fish's skin loses color once it dries out hence there is a special value of this auction item!
The bear is a symbol for strength, courage and tenacity. It is still seen as a great warrior and the male is associated with King Arthur!
It symbolizes strength, rage and perseverance. Also, it's known as the Chinese symbol of good luck. The owner of such a trophy will definitely be associated with these qualities.

The moose head is a symbol of being headstrong, longevity, wisdom, confidence, self-esteem, primal feminine energy and steadfastness. Everyone, who is an admirer of unique decor with a strong energy, should have this exclusive thing!
The boar head symbolizes health and protects against danger. Besides, it is a sacred animal in many counties. Once Richard III chose a white boar as a symbol of courage and ferocity!
It is a symbol of calm and equanimity in any situation because life is like a zebra: either a white stripe or a black one!
This is the skin of the Bengal tiger, killed by the British in the middle of the 19th century. It symbolizes energy, strength and talent!

The Colt Revolving Belt Pistol of Naval Caliber, later known as the Colt 1851 Navy or Navy Revolver, is a cap and ball revolver that was designed by Samuel Colt between 1847 and 1850. The main thing is one of the favorite guns of Wild Bill!
This is an original katana that was made at the beginning of the 18th century. It has a complex structure having 7 layers of steel that was used by the blacksmith Masamune.
Historically, it was a personal weapon of officers engaged in naval hand-to-hand combat during the Age of Sail. What may hit you about it is that the dirk belonged to Peter I!

The firearm that uses a flint striking ignition mechanism. French court gunsmith Marin le Bourgeoys made a firearm incorporating a flintlock mechanism for King Louis XIII shortly after his accession to the throne in 1610, it is the very rifle!
The muzzle-loaded long gun that appeared as a smoothbore weapon in early 16th-century Europe, at first as a heavier variant of the arquebus, capable of penetrating heavy armor.
The Russian flint gun of the sample of 1809 that made during the transition of the Russian army to the 7 line caliber. An interesting fact is that it was A.S.Pushkin's dueling gun!

The type of backsword with a curved blade associated with the light cavalry of the early modern and Napoleonic periods. This is the very saber Napoleon Bonaparte had during the Battle of Marengo was fought on 14 June 1800 between French forces under Napoleon Bonaparte and Austrian forces near the city of Alessandria, in Piedmont, Italy.

This sniper rifle was based upon the colt model 1855 sidehammer pocket revolver developed by Elisha K. Root. The design of the Colt revolving rifle was essentially similar to revolver type pistols, with a rotating cylinder that held five or six rounds in a variety of calibers from .36 to .64 inches.

It was the first commercial repeating firearm employing a revolving cylinder with multiple chambers aligned with a single, stationary barrel. Its design was patented by Samuel Colt on February 25, 1836, in the United States, France, and England, and it derived its name from being produced in Paterson, New Jersey.

It represents how much resources the company spends on the salary of workers, director and board of directors - all this has an effect on the motivation and productivity of workers
Each worker gets unemployment benefits after the termination of employment. The unemployment benefits amount depends on the turnover and working conditions
